Title: Every nonzero element in a finite ring is either a unit or a zero divisor
Content: Let $R$ be a finite ring with unity. Prove that every nonzero element of $R$ is either a unit or a zero-divisor.
AcceptedAnswer: In a finite commutative ring with unity, every element is either a unit or a zero-divisor. Indeed, let $a\in R$ and consider the map on $R$ given by $x \mapsto ax$ . If this map is injective then it has to be surjective, because $R$ is finite. Hence, $1=ax$ for some $x\in R$ and $a$ is a unit. If the map is not injective then there are $u,v\in R$ , with $u\ne v$ , such that $au=av$ . But then $a(u-v)=0$ and $u-v\ne0$ and so $a$ is a zero divisor. For the noncommutative case, see this answer .
